Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of Harpocrates. Upper part broken from a figure of Harpokrates wearing a tunic and with a finger of his left hand to his mouth. He has curly hair with a topknot, and wears a tightly woven and bound wreath, with an outer wreath of vine leaves and a Double Crown rises from the inner wreath. Hollow, from a two-piece mould, with a plain back. Orange-brown Nile silt, with a brown surface and frequent fine mica and sparse fine quartz and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: This example (Bailey 2008, 37; Gutch 1898–9: 92n. 2 and 93n. 8), is similar to one now at Dresden dated to the early second century BC (Fischer 1994, 286, no. 653) and from the same mould as a Naukratis piece in Cambridge Museum of Classical Archaeology (NA641). Fischer, J. 1994. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten aus Ägypten. Die Sammlungen Sieglin und Schreiber. Dresden, Leipzig, Stuttgart, Tübingen. Tübingen: Wasmuth.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (C582)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.056) (Phase 1)
Condition: Surface badly flaked in places. The right arm is lost; an apparent slot below the right shoulder is where a piece of wood, accidentally incorporated, was burnt out during the firing.
